shortDescription: The EB-5 process begins with filing Form I-526 (direct) or I-526E (regional center).
examples: An investor includes bank records, tax returns, and a comprehensive business plan with the I-526 petition.
For regional center projects, I-526E is used and includes the center's documentation.

title: USCIS Review and Processing
description: USCIS reviews the petition for eligibility, fund traceability, and job creation strategy. If needed, they may issue a Request for Evidence (RFE) or Notice of Intent to Deny (NOID).
shortDescription: USCIS reviews the petition for eligibility, fund traceability, and job creation strategy.
examples: USCIS asks for clarification on employment documentation and timeline in an RFE.
An investor submits additional evidence proving lawful source of a gift.

title: Approval and Visa Availability
description: Once Form I-526/I-526E is approved, the investor must check the Visa Bulletin to confirm if a visa is available for their country. If current, they can proceed to apply for a Green Card.
shortDescription: Once Form I-526/I-526E is approved, the investor must check the Visa Bulletin to confirm if a visa is available for their country.
examples: An Indian investor waits for their priority date to become current before moving forward.
Investors from low-demand countries may proceed immediately after I-526 approval.

title: Adjustment of Status or Consular Processing
description: If in the U.S., the investor files Form I-485 for status adjustment. If abroad, they apply through consular processing using DS-260 at a U.S. embassy.
shortDescription: If in the U.S., the investor files Form I-485 for status adjustment.
examples: A student on an F-1 visa in the U.S. files I-485 to adjust to EB-5 status.
An investor living abroad schedules a consulate interview after DS-260 submission.

title: Conditional Green Card Issuance
description: Upon approval of adjustment or consular process, the investor receives a two-year conditional Green Card. They must meet investment and job creation goals within this period.
shortDescription: Upon approval of adjustment or consular process, the investor receives a two-year conditional Green Card.
examples: An investor receives a conditional Green Card and relocates to the U.S. with their family.
The investor receives a conditional Green Card and relocates to manage the business.
The two-year period begins on the date of U.S. entry or adjustment approval.
The two-year period starts from the date of entry or adjustment approval.

title: Filing Form I-829 to Remove Conditions
description: Within 90 days before the second anniversary of receiving a conditional Green Card, the investor must file Form I-829 to prove the investment was sustained and jobs were created.
shortDescription: Within 90 days before the second anniversary of receiving a conditional Green Card, the investor must file Form I-829 to prove the…
examples: The investor includes payroll records, tax documents, and financial statements with I-829.
Failure to timely file I-829 may result in loss of permanent residency.

title: Form I-526 / I-526E – Immigrant Petition
description: Form I-526 (or I-526E for regional center investors) initiates the EB-5 process. It demonstrates the investor’s eligibility, lawful source of funds, and job-creating investment plan.
shortDescription: Form I-526 (or I-526E for regional center investors) initiates the EB-5 process.
examples: A direct EB-5 investor files Form I-526 with proof of investment in a restaurant business.
A regional center participant submits Form I-526E along with the project’s economic report.

title: Form I-485 – Adjustment of Status
description: If the investor is already in the U.S., they file Form I-485 to adjust their status to lawful permanent resident after their I-526 is approved and a visa is available.
shortDescription: If the investor is already in the U.S., they file Form I-485 to adjust their status to lawful permanent resident after their I-526 is…
examples: An investor on an H-1B visa uses I-485 to switch to EB-5 conditional resident status.
Form I-485 includes biometrics, medical exam, and personal history details.

title: Form DS-260 – Consular Processing
description: Investors residing outside the U.S. use Form DS-260 to apply for an immigrant visa at a U.S. consulate after I-526/I-526E approval and visa availability.
shortDescription: Investors residing outside the U.S.
examples: An investor in India completes DS-260 to schedule their visa interview at the U.S. Embassy.
Form DS-260 is submitted online via the National Visa Center portal.

title: Form I-829 – Remove Conditions
description: Filed within 90 days before the two-year conditional period expires, Form I-829 requests removal of conditions and proves that the investor met job creation and investment sustainment requirements.
shortDescription: Filed within 90 days before the two-year conditional period expires, Form I-829 requests removal of conditions and proves that the investor…
examples: The I-829 includes payroll records, business licenses, and investment bank statements.
Once approved, the investor and their family receive permanent Green Cards valid for 10 years.

title: Form I-956K – Agent Registration
description: Any person acting as a promoter, finder, or agent for an EB-5 project must file Form I-956K to disclose their relationship with the regional center and confirm compliance with USCIS regulations.
shortDescription: Any person acting as a promoter, finder, or agent for an EB-5 project must file Form I-956K to disclose their relationship with the…
examples: A marketing agent working with a regional center files I-956K to register with USCIS.
Failure to file I-956K can result in disqualification of investor petitions linked to the agent.

title: Form I-956F – Project Application
description: Form I-956F must be submitted by regional centers for each EB-5 project offering. It contains the project's business plan, economic report, securities documents, and job creation model.
shortDescription: Form I-956F must be submitted by regional centers for each EB-5 project offering.
examples: A regional center submits I-956F with a full set of project documents before investors can file I-526E.
The project must be approved under I-956F for investors to proceed.

title: Rights of Conditional Residents
description: EB-5 conditional Green Card holders have full rights to live, work, and study in the U.S. They can travel, open businesses, and enroll children in public schools.
shortDescription: EB-5 conditional Green Card holders have full rights to live, work, and study in the U.S.
examples: An investor's spouse starts a business while their child attends a U.S. university.
The family is not subject to visa restrictions once conditional status is granted.

title: Conditions Removal via Form I-829
description: To convert the conditional Green Card into a permanent one, the investor must file Form I-829 within the 90-day window before the card expires. This proves investment sustainment and job creation.
shortDescription: To convert the conditional Green Card into a permanent one, the investor must file Form I-829 within the 90-day window before the card…
examples: The investor submits payroll, tax records, and proof of capital use with Form I-829.
Once approved, a 10-year unconditional Green Card is issued.

title: 10-Year Green Card (Permanent Residency)
description: Once Form I-829 is approved, the investor and their qualifying family members receive a permanent Green Card valid for 10 years. It is renewable and serves as proof of lawful permanent residency.
shortDescription: Once Form I-829 is approved, the investor and their qualifying family members receive a permanent Green Card valid for 10 years.
examples: The investor receives a 10-year Green Card and no longer needs to prove job creation.
Family members receive the same permanent status and enjoy full residency rights.

title: Maintaining Green Card Status
description: To keep Green Card status, residents must not abandon their intent to live in the U.S., avoid long absences, and comply with tax and residency obligations.
shortDescription: To keep Green Card status, residents must not abandon their intent to live in the U.S., avoid long absences, and comply with tax and…
examples: Spending more than 6 months abroad could trigger abandonment concerns.
Filing U.S. tax returns and maintaining ties to the U.S. help preserve status.

title: Eligibility for U.S. Citizenship
description: After 5 years of lawful permanent residency (including conditional status), EB-5 investors may apply for naturalization if they meet physical presence, language, and civics requirements.
shortDescription: After 5 years of lawful permanent residency (including conditional status), EB-5 investors may apply for naturalization if they meet…
examples: An investor applies for U.S. citizenship five years after receiving their conditional Green Card.
The naturalization process includes a background check and citizenship interview.

title: Adjustment of Status (AOS) Overview
subcategory: Adjustment of Status vs Consular Processing
description: Adjustment of Status allows EB-5 investors already in the U.S. to change from a nonimmigrant to immigrant status by filing Form I-485 without leaving the country.
shortDescription: Adjustment of Status allows EB-5 investors already in the U.S.
examples: An F-1 student files I-485 after their I-526 approval to become a conditional Green Card holder.
The investor remains in the U.S. during processing and receives a work/travel permit.

title: Consular Processing Overview
subcategory: Adjustment of Status vs Consular Processing
description: Consular processing applies to EB-5 investors living outside the U.S. After I-526/I-526E approval, they apply for an immigrant visa through a U.S. consulate in their home country.
shortDescription: Consular processing applies to EB-5 investors living outside the U.S.
examples: An investor in China schedules a visa interview at the U.S. Consulate in Guangzhou.
After DS-260 approval, the investor receives a visa and enters the U.S. as a conditional resident.

title: AOS Processing Timeline and Benefits
subcategory: Adjustment of Status vs Consular Processing
description: Adjustment of Status often includes faster access to work and travel authorization (EAD/AP) and avoids the need for international travel. Processing time varies by USCIS workload.
shortDescription: Adjustment of Status often includes faster access to work and travel authorization (EAD/AP) and avoids the need for international travel.
examples: A student receives an EAD card within 90 days of filing Form I-485.
Advance parole allows the investor to travel abroad while AOS is pending.

title: Consular Interview and Entry to the U.S.
subcategory: Adjustment of Status vs Consular Processing
description: In consular processing, the applicant must attend a visa interview abroad. Once approved, they enter the U.S. and activate their EB-5 Green Card status upon arrival.
shortDescription: In consular processing, the applicant must attend a visa interview abroad.
examples: The visa stamp is issued by the consulate after the medical exam and background checks.
The Green Card is mailed after the investor enters the U.S. through a port of entry.

title: Factors in Choosing Between AOS and Consular
subcategory: Adjustment of Status vs Consular Processing
description: Choosing between Adjustment of Status and Consular Processing depends on current location, visa availability, travel needs, and immigration history. Legal counsel is often necessary.
shortDescription: Choosing between Adjustment of Status and Consular Processing depends on current location, visa availability, travel needs, and immigration…
examples: A business visitor on a B-1 visa may not qualify for AOS due to intent issues.
An H-1B worker with dual intent can safely use AOS while remaining employed.

title: Travel Considerations During Processing
subcategory: Adjustment of Status vs Consular Processing
description: Those applying for AOS must avoid international travel without advance parole. Consular applicants should remain abroad until their visa is issued to avoid denial.
shortDescription: Those applying for AOS must avoid international travel without advance parole.
examples: An AOS applicant who travels without a travel document risks petition abandonment.
Consular processing requires patience while awaiting interview scheduling overseas.

title: Role of Immigration Attorneys
description: Immigration attorneys provide legal advice, prepare and file EB-5 forms, and help ensure compliance with USCIS regulations. They are licensed and regulated professionals with expertise in immigration law.
shortDescription: Immigration attorneys provide legal advice, prepare and file EB-5 forms, and help ensure compliance with USCIS regulations.
examples: An attorney drafts Form I-526 and reviews the business plan for compliance with Matter of Ho.
The attorney communicates with USCIS and responds to Requests for Evidence (RFEs).

title: Choosing a Qualified EB-5 Attorney
description: Investors should select attorneys with EB-5 experience, strong references, and a track record of approvals. Avoid generalists or those without a deep understanding of EB-5 rules and compliance.
shortDescription: Investors should select attorneys with EB-5 experience, strong references, and a track record of approvals.
examples: An experienced EB-5 attorney helps avoid common errors in job creation documentation.
Checking client testimonials and approval history can help assess credibility.

title: Role of Migration Agents and Consultants
description: Migration agents and consultants assist with project selection, documentation, and coordination with legal teams. They are not licensed to provide legal advice unless they are also attorneys.
shortDescription: Migration agents and consultants assist with project selection, documentation, and coordination with legal teams.
examples: An agent helps the investor evaluate regional center projects and submit financial records.
Non-attorney consultants cannot provide legal opinions or represent clients before USCIS.

title: Agent Registration Requirement (I-956K)
description: Under the EB-5 Reform and Integrity Act, all agents promoting EB-5 projects must file Form I-956K with USCIS. This ensures transparency and accountability in the investment process.
shortDescription: Under the EB-5 Reform and Integrity Act, all agents promoting EB-5 projects must file Form I-956K with USCIS.
examples: A consultant promoting an EB-5 project must register via I-956K before marketing to investors.
Failure to register may disqualify the investor’s petition.

title: Avoiding Fraudulent Consultants
description: Investors should be cautious of unregistered agents, exaggerated claims, or guarantees of success. Only licensed attorneys should handle legal filings and strategy.
shortDescription: Investors should be cautious of unregistered agents, exaggerated claims, or guarantees of success.
examples: An agent promising guaranteed Green Cards is likely violating EB-5 laws.
The investor checks a consultant’s I-956K registration and legal background before engagement.

title: Working With a Professional Team
description: Successful EB-5 applicants often work with a team of professionals including attorneys, financial planners, project analysts, and translators to ensure accuracy and completeness.
shortDescription: Successful EB-5 applicants often work with a team of professionals including attorneys, financial planners, project analysts, and…
examples: The investor’s team includes an immigration attorney, CPA, and EB-5 consultant.
A collaborative approach ensures legal compliance and proper fund documentation.

title: Insufficient Job Creation
description: Failure to create at least 10 full-time qualifying jobs is a leading reason for EB-5 petition denials, especially at the I-829 stage.
shortDescription: Failure to create at least 10 full-time qualifying jobs is a leading reason for EB-5 petition denials, especially at the I-829 stage.
examples: A project anticipated 12 jobs per investor but only created 8, resulting in denial.
Lack of payroll records or credible economic modeling can trigger job-related RFE.

title: Unclear or Unverifiable Source of Funds
description: USCIS requires detailed documentation of how the investor lawfully obtained and transferred funds. Any gaps, inconsistencies, or suspicious transactions may lead to a denial.
shortDescription: USCIS requires detailed documentation of how the investor lawfully obtained and transferred funds.
examples: An investor failed to document a large wire transfer received from an offshore account.
Missing tax returns or sale deeds raised concerns about fund legality.

title: Improper Use of Escrow or Loan Terms
description: Agreements that guarantee a return of capital or tie investment to repayment timelines violate EB-5's 'at risk' rule and result in USCIS denial.
shortDescription: Agreements that guarantee a return of capital or tie investment to repayment timelines violate EB-5's 'at risk' rule and result in USCIS…
examples: A side agreement promised capital return within five years regardless of job creation.
The investor’s funds never left escrow, so they were not considered at risk.

title: Inadequate Business Plan
description: A business plan that lacks credibility, detail, or job creation strategy may fail to meet Matter of Ho standards and lead to denial at the I-526 or I-829 stage.
shortDescription: A business plan that lacks credibility, detail, or job creation strategy may fail to meet Matter of Ho standards and lead to denial at the…
examples: The plan did not show specific hiring schedules or employment structure.
Projected jobs were not clearly tied to capital deployment.

title: Late or Missed Filings
description: Failing to file Form I-829 within 90 days before the conditional Green Card expires can result in loss of residency and denial, even if the project met all other requirements.
shortDescription: Failing to file Form I-829 within 90 days before the conditional Green Card expires can result in loss of residency and denial, even if the…
examples: An investor missed the I-829 deadline and lost lawful permanent resident status.
Even a strong case may be denied if it is filed late or lacks a valid explanation.

title: Fraud or Misrepresentation
description: Providing false documents or misrepresenting facts in any part of the EB-5 process can result in petition denial, permanent inadmissibility, and legal consequences.
shortDescription: Providing false documents or misrepresenting facts in any part of the EB-5 process can result in petition denial, permanent…
examples: An investor claimed job creation that was later proven fabricated by USCIS audit.
Falsifying income statements led to a permanent bar from entering the U.S.

title: Eligibility of Spouse and Children
description: The EB-5 program allows the investor's spouse and unmarried children under the age of 21 to receive conditional Green Cards as derivative beneficiaries.
shortDescription: The EB-5 program allows the investor's spouse and unmarried children under the age of 21 to receive conditional Green Cards as derivative…
examples: An investor applies with their spouse and two minor children, who all receive Green Cards.
Each family member is included in the same I-526 or I-526E petition.

title: Education and Work Rights for Family
description: Family members who receive Green Cards can study in public or private schools and are eligible to work in the U.S. without additional permits.
shortDescription: Family members who receive Green Cards can study in public or private schools and are eligible to work in the U.S.
examples: A child of an EB-5 investor enrolls in a state university and qualifies for in-state tuition.
The investor’s spouse begins work at a healthcare clinic after receiving their Green Card.

title: Maintaining Dependent Status
description: Children must remain unmarried and under age 21 at the time of visa issuance to qualify as dependents. The Child Status Protection Act (CSPA) may help preserve eligibility despite delays.
shortDescription: Children must remain unmarried and under age 21 at the time of visa issuance to qualify as dependents.
examples: A child turns 21 during petition processing but remains eligible under CSPA.
If the child marries, they lose eligibility as a derivative beneficiary.

title: Permanent Residency for Family
description: After Form I-829 is approved, all eligible family members receive unconditional Green Cards and retain permanent residency rights independently from the main investor.
shortDescription: After Form I-829 is approved, all eligible family members receive unconditional Green Cards and retain permanent residency rights…
examples: The investor’s spouse and children receive 10-year Green Cards after I-829 approval.
Family members are not required to reapply separately—they are included in the I-829.

title: Future Family Sponsorship Options
description: Once an EB-5 investor becomes a permanent resident or citizen, they may sponsor other relatives such as parents, adult children, or siblings through family-based immigration channels.
shortDescription: Once an EB-5 investor becomes a permanent resident or citizen, they may sponsor other relatives such as parents, adult children, or…
examples: A naturalized investor files an immigrant petition for their elderly parents.
Family sponsorship is not part of EB-5 but may follow once Green Card or citizenship is obtained.

title: Risk of Business Failure
description: EB-5 investments are subject to the same risks as any commercial venture. If the business fails, the investor may lose both their capital and eligibility for permanent residency.
shortDescription: EB-5 investments are subject to the same risks as any commercial venture.
examples: A restaurant closes due to poor location and market conditions, failing to create jobs.
The investor cannot remove conditions without proving successful investment outcomes.

title: Job Creation Shortfall
description: If a project does not create or sustain at least 10 full-time jobs per investor, USCIS may deny the I-829 petition and permanent residency will not be granted.
shortDescription: If a project does not create or sustain at least 10 full-time jobs per investor, USCIS may deny the I-829 petition and permanent residency…
examples: Construction delays prevent job creation during the conditional period.
Underperformance leads to staff layoffs before jobs can be documented.

title: Project Delays or Cancellations
description: Development projects may face delays due to permitting issues, financing gaps, or external economic factors, which can affect EB-5 timelines and compliance.
shortDescription: Development projects may face delays due to permitting issues, financing gaps, or external economic factors, which can affect EB-5…
examples: A hotel project is delayed due to zoning disputes, pushing job creation beyond the required window.
The investor's I-829 filing is postponed due to construction not reaching job milestones.

title: Visa Backlogs and Country Caps
description: Applicants from countries with high EB-5 demand may face long waiting periods due to annual visa limits per country, which can delay Green Card issuance even after investment approval.
shortDescription: Applicants from countries with high EB-5 demand may face long waiting periods due to annual visa limits per country, which can delay Green…
examples: Investors from India and China often experience multi-year delays due to oversubscription.
A child's age-out risk increases while waiting for a visa number to become available.

title: Risk of Fraud or Mismanagement
description: Investors may be vulnerable to dishonest project sponsors or unregistered agents. Fraudulent or mismanaged projects can lead to financial loss and petition denial.
shortDescription: Investors may be vulnerable to dishonest project sponsors or unregistered agents.
examples: The Jay Peak case involved misuse of investor funds and led to major USCIS reforms.
An investor unknowingly joins a project with inflated job projections and poor execution.

title: Economic and Political Risks
description: Market downturns, interest rate changes, inflation, or immigration policy shifts can all impact EB-5 investments, either financially or procedurally.
shortDescription: Market downturns, interest rate changes, inflation, or immigration policy shifts can all impact EB-5 investments, either financially or…
examples: A recession reduces hotel revenue, limiting job creation and investor returns.
Legislative delays in EB-5 reauthorization create program uncertainty.

title: Understanding Project Structure
description: Before investing, EB-5 applicants should understand how the project is structured—who the developers are, how funds are used, and what roles each party plays.
shortDescription: Before investing, EB-5 applicants should understand how the project is structured—who the developers are, how funds are used, and what…
examples: An investor reviews a project’s organizational chart and capital stack diagram.
A reputable developer with a clear track record reduces project risk.

title: Assessing Regional Center Credentials
description: Review the experience, approval history, and integrity of the regional center sponsoring the project. A strong compliance record and I-829 approval rates are key indicators.
shortDescription: Review the experience, approval history, and integrity of the regional center sponsoring the project.
examples: A regional center with hundreds of successful petitions is more reliable.
The investor requests a history of job creation and capital return from past projects.

title: Reviewing Economic Reports
description: Third-party economic impact reports help determine whether job creation projections are realistic and based on sound modeling techniques.
shortDescription: Third-party economic impact reports help determine whether job creation projections are realistic and based on sound modeling techniques.
examples: The IMPLAN report forecasts job creation based on $100M in construction spending.
The investor ensures that job buffers exceed the 10-job minimum requirement.

title: Legal and Financial Review
description: A thorough legal and financial review helps uncover potential red flags. Investors should engage attorneys and financial advisors to evaluate offering documents and escrow arrangements.
shortDescription: A thorough legal and financial review helps uncover potential red flags.
examples: An attorney reviews the PPM and escrow agreements to verify fund flow and risk disclosures.
A financial expert examines whether the return model is realistic and SEC-compliant.

title: Background Checks on Sponsors
description: Conduct background checks on the developers, general partners, or managers of the EB-5 project to identify litigation history, bankruptcies, or other red flags.
shortDescription: Conduct background checks on the developers, general partners, or managers of the EB-5 project to identify litigation history,…
examples: A background search reveals a principal previously involved in a failed EB-5 project.
Investors verify that all key parties are in good legal standing.

title: Evaluating Exit Strategy
description: A clearly defined exit strategy gives investors a roadmap for when and how they may receive return of capital. Look for realistic timelines and market-supported projections.
shortDescription: A clearly defined exit strategy gives investors a roadmap for when and how they may receive return of capital.
examples: The plan includes a projected refinance or property sale in year six.
Vague or overly optimistic exit language may signal potential risk.

title: Recognizing Red Flags
description: Investors should be alert to signs of potential fraud, such as unrealistic return promises, lack of transparency, unregistered agents, or unverifiable project details.
shortDescription: Investors should be alert to signs of potential fraud, such as unrealistic return promises, lack of transparency, unregistered agents, or…
examples: A project guarantees both immigration success and capital return—an immediate red flag.
The regional center refuses to disclose detailed financials or ownership structure.

title: Verifying Agent and Project Registration
description: Investors should ensure their project is associated with a USCIS-approved regional center and that any intermediaries have filed Form I-956K to register with USCIS.
shortDescription: Investors should ensure their project is associated with a USCIS-approved regional center and that any intermediaries have filed Form…
examples: The investor checks USCIS’s website for the regional center’s designation.
An agent shows their I-956K confirmation before offering EB-5 services.

title: Requesting Escrow Account Transparency
description: Escrow accounts help safeguard investor capital. Investors should request documentation on escrow agents, release conditions, and legal oversight.
shortDescription: Escrow accounts help safeguard investor capital.
examples: The investor receives a copy of the escrow agreement outlining release upon I-526 approval.
A third-party escrow manager confirms controls over fund access.

title: Reviewing Offering Documents Carefully
description: Thoroughly review the private placement memorandum (PPM), subscription agreement, and business plan. All disclosures, risks, and terms must be clearly outlined and realistic.
shortDescription: Thoroughly review the private placement memorandum (PPM), subscription agreement, and business plan.
examples: A lawyer reviews the PPM and flags inconsistencies in the job creation model.
The investor verifies that capital repayment terms align with EB-5 regulations.

title: Use of Independent Legal and Financial Advisors
description: Independent advisors not affiliated with the project can provide unbiased opinions and detect fraud risk. Investors should avoid relying solely on project representatives.
shortDescription: Independent advisors not affiliated with the project can provide unbiased opinions and detect fraud risk.
examples: An unaffiliated immigration lawyer reviews compliance with USCIS requirements.
An independent CPA evaluates financial projections and fund flow.

title: Understanding EB-5 Program Rules
description: Educating oneself on EB-5 rules reduces vulnerability to misrepresentation. Investors should understand investment, job creation, and sustainment requirements before committing funds.
shortDescription: Educating oneself on EB-5 rules reduces vulnerability to misrepresentation.
examples: An investor learns that guaranteed returns are not allowed under EB-5 law.
Familiarity with Form I-526 content helps the investor identify missing evidence.

title: Understanding Exit Strategy Basics
description: An exit strategy outlines how and when EB-5 investors may be repaid their capital after completing immigration requirements. It is a critical part of project evaluation.
shortDescription: An exit strategy outlines how and when EB-5 investors may be repaid their capital after completing immigration requirements.
examples: The project plan includes a proposed refinance event in year 6.
An exit strategy tied to asset sale post-job creation period helps ensure compliance.

title: Exit via Refinancing
description: Many projects plan to repay EB-5 investors through refinancing after stabilization. This is common in real estate where revenue streams support new financing to replace EB-5 capital.
shortDescription: Many projects plan to repay EB-5 investors through refinancing after stabilization.
examples: A multifamily apartment complex is refinanced by a bank loan, allowing EB-5 investors to exit.
Refinancing occurs once occupancy reaches 90% and NOI targets are met.

title: Exit via Property Sale
description: Some EB-5 projects plan to sell the developed asset after completion and job creation. Proceeds from the sale are then used to repay investors.
shortDescription: Some EB-5 projects plan to sell the developed asset after completion and job creation.
examples: The developer sells a hotel to a private equity firm at a target price to repay EB-5 funds.
An industrial warehouse is sold post-lease up to institutional buyers.

title: Exit via Revenue Sharing
description: In rare cases, EB-5 investments are repaid over time through revenue sharing. While less common, this method may be used when long-term income supports scheduled distributions.
shortDescription: In rare cases, EB-5 investments are repaid over time through revenue sharing.
examples: An entertainment venue uses ticket revenue to return investor capital over 8 years.
The business provides quarterly reports and dividend payments based on performance.

title: Restrictions on Exit Timing
description: EB-5 funds must remain invested and at risk for the full sustainment period. Early exits are not permitted before the investor files Form I-829. Exit strategies must account for this timing.
shortDescription: EB-5 funds must remain invested and at risk for the full sustainment period.
examples: Investors cannot be repaid until after their two-year conditional residency period ends.
A refinance is planned only after the last I-829 filing window is complete.

title: Transparency in Exit Planning
description: The exit strategy must be clearly disclosed in offering documents. Investors should seek transparency on timing, repayment method, contingencies, and legal structure.
shortDescription: The exit strategy must be clearly disclosed in offering documents.
examples: The Private Placement Memorandum outlines refinance terms, timeline, and potential risks.
Investors review exit terms with legal counsel before committing capital.

title: Legal Review of Offering Documents
description: Investors should have legal counsel review the Private Placement Memorandum (PPM), subscription agreement, and all offering materials to identify risks and confirm EB-5 compliance.
shortDescription: Investors should have legal counsel review the Private Placement Memorandum (PPM), subscription agreement, and all offering materials to…
examples: An immigration attorney flags discrepancies in the capital deployment section of the PPM.
A securities lawyer confirms that investor rights are clearly protected in the agreement.

title: Third-Party Fund Administration
description: Independent fund administrators ensure proper accounting and fund use tracking. They provide transparency and reduce the risk of misuse by developers or regional centers.
shortDescription: Independent fund administrators ensure proper accounting and fund use tracking.
examples: A third-party fund manager monitors capital deployment and provides quarterly reports to investors.
Investors request verification from the administrator before approving fund release.

title: Developer Equity Commitment
description: Projects where developers contribute significant equity show strong alignment with investor interests. This reduces risk and enhances the likelihood of project completion and capital preservation.
shortDescription: Projects where developers contribute significant equity show strong alignment with investor interests.
examples: The developer contributes 20% of project costs from their own funds before accepting EB-5 capital.
High equity participation demonstrates commitment and financial stability.

title: Securities Compliance and Disclosures
description: EB-5 investments must comply with U.S. securities laws. Disclosures must clearly explain risks, fees, conflicts of interest, and use of funds. Proper registration or exemption is required.
shortDescription: EB-5 investments must comply with U.S.
examples: The PPM includes required disclosures under Regulation D of the SEC.
Misleading or missing information may expose the issuer to liability and jeopardize the investor’s status.

title: Regular Reporting and Transparency
description: Ongoing updates and disclosures help investors monitor progress and compliance. Trusted projects share construction milestones, job creation data, and financial updates on a routine basis.
shortDescription: Ongoing updates and disclosures help investors monitor progress and compliance.
examples: The investor receives monthly updates from the project with job metrics and timelines.
Transparent communication improves confidence and helps identify issues early.
